Mixed Federated Learning:
Joint Decentralized and Centralized Learning

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) enables learning from decentralized privacy-sensitive data, with computations on raw data confined to take place at edge clients. This paper introduces mixed FL, which incorporates an additional loss term calculated at the coordinating server (while maintaining FLâ€™s private data restrictions). There are numerous benefits. For example, additional datacenter data can be leveraged to jointly learn from centralized (datacenter) and decentralized (federated) training data and better match an expected inference data distribution. Mixed FL also enables offloading some intensive computations (e.g., embedding regularization) to the server, greatly reducing communication and client computation load. For these and other mixed FL use cases, we present three algorithms: Parallel Training, 1-way Gradient Transfer, and 2-way Gradient Transfer. We state convergence bounds for each, and give intuition on which are suited to particular mixed FL problems. Finally we perform extensive experiments on three tasks, demonstrating that mixed FL can blend training data to achieve an oracleâ€™s accuracy on an inference distribution, and can reduce communication and computation overhead by over 90%. Our experiments confirm theoretical predictions of how algorithms perform under different mixed FL problem settings.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL)Â (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is a machine learning setting where multiple â€˜clientsâ€™ (e.g., mobile phones) collaborate to train a model under coordination of a central server. Clientsâ€™ raw data are never transferred. Instead, focused updates intended for immediate aggregation are used to achieve the learning objectiveÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019). FL typically delivers model quality improvements because training examples gathered in situ by clients reflect actual inference serving requests. For example, a mobile keyboard next-word prediction model can be trained from actual SMS messages, yielding higher accuracy than a model trained on a proxy document corpus. Because of the benefits, FL has been used to train production models for many applicationsÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2018; Ramaswamy etÂ al., 2019; Apple, 2019; Ramaswamy etÂ al., 2020; Hartmann, 2021; Hard etÂ al., 2022).

Building on FL, we can gain significant benefits from â€˜mixed FLâ€™: jointly111We use â€˜jointâ€™ to distinguish our work from sequential â€˜central-then-FLâ€™ use cases, e.g. transfer learning. training with an additional centralized objective in conjunction with the decentralized objective of FL. Let ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} be model parameters to be optimized. Let fğ‘“f denote a mixed loss, a sum222To simplify we subsume any relative weights into loss terms, i.e. this can be fâ€‹(ğ’™)=(wfâ€‹ff~â€‹(ğ’™))+(wcâ€‹fc~â€‹(ğ’™))ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ‘¤f~subscriptğ‘“fğ’™subscriptğ‘¤c~subscriptğ‘“cğ’™f(\bm{x})=(w_{\textrm{f}}\tilde{f_{\textrm{f}}}(\bm{x}))+(w_{\textrm{c}}\tilde{f_{\textrm{c}}}(\bm{x})).Â of a federated loss ffsubscriptğ‘“ff_{\textrm{f}} and a centralized loss fcsubscriptğ‘“cf_{\textrm{c}}:

fâ€‹(ğ’™)=ffâ€‹(ğ’™)+fcâ€‹(ğ’™)ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ‘“fğ’™subscriptğ‘“cğ’™f(\bm{x})=f_{\textrm{f}}(\bm{x})+f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}) (1)

Mixed loss fğ‘“f might be a more useful training objective than ffsubscriptğ‘“ff_{\textrm{f}} for many reasons, including:

Mitigating Distribution Shift by Adding Centralized Data to FL

While FL helps with reducing train vs.Â inference distribution skew, it may not remove it completely. Examples include: training device populations that are subsets of inference device populations (e.g., training on high-end phones, for eventual use also on low-end phones), label-biased example retention on edge clients (e.g., only retaining positive examples of a binary classification task), and infrequent safety-critical example events with outsized importance (e.g., automotive hard-braking events needed to train a self-driving AI) (Augenstein etÂ al., 2021). The benefits of FL can be achieved while overcoming remaining distribution skew by incorporating data from an additional datacenter dataset, via mixed FL. This affords a composite set of training data that better matches the inference distribution.

Reducing Client Computation and Communication

In representation learning, negative examples are used to push dissimilar items apart in a latent space while keeping positive examples closer together (Oord etÂ al., 2018). In federated settings, clientsâ€™ caches may have limited local negative examples, and recent work (Ning etÂ al., 2021) shows this significantly degrades performance compared to centralized learning. This work also shows that using a regularization term to push representations apart, instead of negative examples, can resolve this performance gap. However, if done naively this requires communicating and computing over a large embedding table, introducing massive overhead for large-scale tasks. Applying mixed FL by computing the regularization term at the server avoids communicating the embedding table to clients and greatly reduces client computation.

Though mixed FL can clearly be useful, an actual process to minimize fğ‘“f is not trivial. FL requires that clientsâ€™ data stay on device, as they contain private information that possibly reveals personal identity. Moreover, centralized loss/data is expected to differ significantly333Were they not to differ, one could treat a centralized compute node as an additional client in standard FL, and simply make use of an established FL algorithm like FedAvg for training ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x}.Â from client loss/data.

FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is a ubiquitous, heuristic FL method designed to minimize Equation 2 w.r.t.Â model ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} in a manner that allows all client data (â„¬isubscriptâ„¬ğ‘–\mathcal{B}_{i}) to remain at respective clients iğ‘–i. Providing strong privacy protection is a major motivation for FL. Storing raw data locally on clients rather than replicating it on servers decreases the attack surface of the system. Also, using focused ephemeral updates and early aggregation follows principles of data minimizationÂ (White House Report, 2013).444Even stronger privacy properties are possible when FL is combined with technologies such as differential privacy (DP) and secure multiparty computation (SMPC)Â (Wang etÂ al., 2021).

Such a loss term can make use of batches of centralized data examples â„¬csubscriptâ„¬c\mathcal{B}_{\textrm{c}}, from a datacenter dataset:

    Parallel Training performs a round of FedAvg (minimizing ffsubscriptğ‘“ff_{\textrm{f}}) in parallel with steps of centralized training (minimizing fcsubscriptğ‘“cf_{\textrm{c}}), merges (e.g., averages) the respective updates, and repeats. 3 Related Work

Parallel Training and 1-way Gradient Transfer were presented in an early form in Augenstein etÂ al. (2021). This paper greatly expands on mixed FL, with an additional algorithm (2-way Gradient Transfer), convergence proofs, more use cases, and extensive experiments.

There are parallels between Gradient Transfer and algorithms aimed at addressing inter-client data heterogeneity in standard FL, like SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b) or MimeÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020a). These algorithms calculate a gradient reflective of the federated client population as a whole and transmit it to clients to reduce update variance, improving optimization on non-IID client datasets. In contrast, Gradient Transfer calculates a gradient that is reflective of centralized data/loss, to augment computations based on decentralized data/loss at the federated clients (and in 2-way Gradient Transfer, also the converse). SCAFFOLD also requires keeping state at the server (in the form of control variates) for each participating client, which is impractical in real large-scale FL systems. 2-way Gradient Transfer only requires state (in the form of augmenting gradients) for two entities, the centralized and federated data/losses, and so is easily implemented.

Another mixed FL algorithm is Example Transfer (Augenstein etÂ al., 2021; Zhao etÂ al., 2018), where centralized examples are sent directly to federated clients (as opposed to calculating gradients and sending those instead). This is typically precluded in real FL applications, as the volume of data needed to transfer is excessive. Therefore, this paper focuses on alternative strategies. Split learning (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018) is an alternative to Example Transfer where some layers of a model are computed by a client and others by another client or a server, via communication of layer activations and gradients. Unlike mixed FL, this approach does not train a model to perform well on centralized data. Other works that partition models into global and local parts (Singhal etÂ al., 2021; Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019) also do not optimize the mixed FL objective.

Transfer learning (a.k.a.Â â€˜fine-tuningâ€™) also involves two different distributions at training time, but with a clear difference of objective from mixed FL. In transfer learning, a model is pre-trained on a distribution (e.g., centralized data in a datacenter), then further trained on the actual distribution of interest (e.g., decentralized data via FL). It is desirable as a way to quickly train on the latter distribution (e.g., as inÂ Ro etÂ al. (2022)). But the sequential approach of transfer learning results in catastrophic forgettingÂ (McCloskey and Cohen, 1989; Ratcliff, 1990; French, 1999); accuracy on the pre-training distribution is lost as the model learns to fit the fine-tuning data instead. In mixed FL, we seek strategies yielding good inference performance against all data distributions trained on.

In differentially private (DP) optimization, a line of work has aimed to improve privacy/utility tradeoffs by utilizing additional non-private data. One way is to use non-private data to pre-train (Abadi etÂ al., 2016). Another avenue is to use non-private data to learn the gradient geometry (Zhou etÂ al., 2020; Amid etÂ al., 2021; Asi etÂ al., 2021; Kairouz etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2022), improving accuracy by enabling tighter, non-isotropic gradient noise during DP optimization. Amid etÂ al. (2021) and Li etÂ al. (2022) consider the FL use case555An interesting similarity between PDA-DPMD (Amid etÂ al., 2021) and our work: in PDA-DPMD for FL, a first order approximation of mirror descent is used, where the server model update is calculated as weighted sum of private (federated) and public loss terms, just as in Parallel Training or 2-way Gradient Transfer.. As in transfer learning, additional data is used only to improve performance on a single distribution, and retaining accuracy on other distributions is a non-goal (in contrast to mixed FL). Also, the non-private data used is generally matching (in distribution) to the private data, whereas in mixed FL we typically explicitly leverage distinct distributions.

We focus on the impact to convergence when differences exist between the federated and centralized losses/data. Our analysis can be easily extended to heterogeneous clients by assuming a bound on variance of the client gradients.

4.2 Bounds

We can now state upper bounds on convergence (to an error smaller than Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) for the respective mixed FL algorithms. For ease of comparison, the convergence bounds are summarized in Table 1. The Theorems and Proofs of these convergence bounds are given in Appendix B. As mentioned previously, the analysis extends in a straightforward manner to the setting of heterogeneous clients assuming a bound on the variance of client gradients: for all ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x}, 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡ffâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤Ïƒf21ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“fğ’™2superscriptsubscriptğœf2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}(\bm{x})\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{\textrm{f}}^{2} for some Ïƒfâ‰¥0subscriptğœf0\sigma_{\textrm{f}}\geq 0. Under this assumption, the bounds in Table 1 change by an additional Kâ€‹Ïƒf2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœf2K\sigma_{\textrm{f}}^{2} term in the expression involving Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} and Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} in the parenthesis on the numerator of the leading term. We omit the detailed analysis since it doesnâ€™t provide additional insight.

Analyzing Table 1, there are several implications to be drawn.

Significant (GğºG,BğµB)-BGD impedes Parallel Training

The convergence bounds for Parallel Training show a dependence on the GğºG and BğµB parameters from Definition 4.2. If a mixed FL problem involves a large amount of dissimilarity between the federated and centralized gradients (i.e., if Gâ‰«0much-greater-thanğº0G\gg 0 or Bâ‰«1much-greater-thanğµ1B\gg 1), then Parallel Training will be slower to converge than alternatives.

Significant Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} impedes 1-way Gradient Transfer

1-way Gradient Transfer is more sensitive to central variance Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2}. Unlike the other algorithms, the impact of Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} on convergence scales with the number of steps Kğ¾K. 1-way Gradient Transfer requires a central batch size |â„¬c|subscriptâ„¬ğ‘\left|\mathcal{B}_{c}\right| that is Kğ¾K times larger to achieve the same impact on convergence. Intuitively, this makes sense; in a round, Parallel Training and 2-way Gradient Transfer sample Kğ¾K fresh batches during centralized optimization, while 1-way Gradient Transfer only samples a single central batch.

2-way Gradient Transfer should always converge at least as well as others

The convergence bound for 2-way Gradient Transfer is unaffected by gradient dissimilarity (i.e., Gâ‰«0much-greater-thanğº0G\gg 0 or Bâ‰«1much-greater-thanğµ1B\gg 1), unlike Parallel Training. Also, the bound for 2-way Gradient Transfer is less sensitive to Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} than the bound for 1-way Gradient Transfer (as described above).

4.3 Metrics

Parallel Training has a convergence bound substantially different than the Gradient Transfer algorithms; the dependence on the BGD parameters GğºG and BğµB indicates there are mixed FL problems where Parallel Training is slower to converge than Gradient Transfer (in either form). How can we know if a particular problem is one where Parallel Training will have slower convergence? It would be useful to know GğºG and BğµB, but they cannot be exactly measured. GğºG and BğµB (Definition 4.2) are upper bounds holding âˆ€ğ’™for-allğ’™\forall\bm{x}, and the entire space of ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} cannot realistically be checked. Instead, we introduce sampled approximations to empirically estimate these upper bounds.

Let ğ’™(t)superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\bm{x}^{(t)} be the global model at start of round tğ‘¡t. Let âˆ‡ff~tsubscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“fğ‘¡\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}}_{t}, âˆ‡fc~tsubscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ‘¡\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}}_{t}, âˆ‡f~tsubscript~âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¡\tilde{\nabla f}_{t} be approximations of federated, centralized, total gradients at round tğ‘¡t. Considering Definition 4.2, we define G~tsubscript~ğºğ‘¡\tilde{G}_{t} as a sampled approximation of GğºG assuming B=1ğµ1B=1, and B~tsubscript~ğµğ‘¡\tilde{B}_{t} as a sampled approximation of BğµB assuming G=0ğº0G=0:

âˆ‡ff~t=1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®(giâ€‹(ğ’™(t))),âˆ‡fc~t=gcâ€‹(ğ’™(t)),âˆ‡f~t=âˆ‡ff~t+âˆ‡fc~tG~t2=1wfâ€‹â€–âˆ‡ff~tâ€–2+1wcâ€‹â€–âˆ‡fc~tâ€–2âˆ’â€–âˆ‡f~tâ€–2,B~t2=(1wfâ€‹â€–âˆ‡ff~tâ€–2+1wcâ€‹â€–âˆ‡fc~tâ€–2)/â€–âˆ‡f~tâ€–2formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“fğ‘¡1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–ğ’®subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡formulae-sequencesubscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ‘¡subscriptğ‘”csuperscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscript~âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¡subscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“fğ‘¡subscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ‘¡superscriptsubscript~ğºğ‘¡21subscriptğ‘¤fsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“fğ‘¡21subscriptğ‘¤csuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ‘¡2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript~âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscript~ğµğ‘¡21subscriptğ‘¤fsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“fğ‘¡21subscriptğ‘¤csuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ‘¡2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript~âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¡2\begin{split}\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}}_{t}=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}}\left(g_{i}(\bm{x}^{(t)})\right),\quad\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}}_{t}&=g_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}^{(t)}),\quad\tilde{\nabla f}_{t}=\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}}_{t}+\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}}_{t}\\ \tilde{G}_{t}^{2}=\frac{1}{w_{\textrm{f}}}\left\|\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}}_{t}\right\|^{2}+\frac{1}{w_{\textrm{c}}}\left\|\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}}_{t}\right\|^{2}-\left\|\tilde{\nabla f}_{t}\right\|^{2},&\quad\tilde{B}_{t}^{2}=\left(\frac{1}{w_{\textrm{f}}}\left\|\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}}_{t}\right\|^{2}+\frac{1}{w_{\textrm{c}}}\left\|\tilde{\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}}_{t}\right\|^{2}\right)/\left\|\tilde{\nabla f}_{t}\right\|^{2}\end{split} (7)

These are used to predict relative convergence performance on several mixed FL problems, next.

5 Experiments

We now present experiments on three tasks, showing the range of problems where mixed FL is useful and demonstrating how each algorithm is differently suited depending on properties of the problem.

5.1 Addressing Label Imbalance in Training Data, for Smile Classification (CelebA)

Earlier work (Augenstein etÂ al., 2021) motivated mixed FL with the example problem of training a â€˜smilingâ€™-vs.-â€˜unsmilingâ€™ classifier via FL with mobile phones, with the challenge that the phonesâ€™ camera application (by the nature of its usage) tends to only persist images of smiling faces. The solution for this severe label imbalance was to apply mixed FL, utilizing an additional datacenter dataset of unsmiling faces to train a capable classifier. To experiment, CelebA data999CelebA federated data available via open source FL softwareÂ (TFF CelebA documentation, 2022).Â (Liu etÂ al., 2015; Caldas etÂ al., 2018) was split into a federated â€˜smilingâ€™ dataset and centralized â€˜unsmilingâ€™ dataset.

In that work, it was empirically observed that 1-way Gradient Transfer converged faster than Parallel Training. Figures 1a and 2a show the AUC and loss convergence, adding in 2-way Gradient Transfer (first introduced in this paper)101010For training hyperparameters, additional experiments, and other details, see Appendix C.. Note that 2-way Gradient Transfer performs as good or better than the other algorithms. The analysis of Section 4 provides the explanation for the empirical observation that Gradient Transfer converges faster than Parallel Training. As discussed, Parallel Training is at a disadvantage when Gâ‰«0much-greater-thanğº0G\gg 0 or Bâ‰«1much-greater-thanğµ1B\gg 1, and Table 2 (left column) shows that G~tsubscript~ğºğ‘¡\tilde{G}_{t} is significantly large in this problem.

5.2 Mitigating Bias in Training Data, for Language Modeling (Stack Overflow, Wikipedia)

We now study a case where the comparative behavior of the mixed FL algorithms is different. Consider the problem of learning a language model like a RNN-based next character prediction model, used to make typing suggestions to a user in a mobile keyboard application. Because the ultimate inference application is on mobile phones, it is natural to train this model via FL, leveraging cached SMS text content highly reflective of inference time usage (at least for some users).

However, the mobile phones participating in the federated learning of the model might be only a subset of the mobile phones for which we desire to deploy for inference. Higher-end mobile phones can disproportionately participate in FL, as their larger memory and faster processors allow them to complete client training faster. But to do well at inference, a model should make accurate predictions for users of lower-end phones as well. A purely FL approach can do an inadequate job of learning these usersâ€™ usage patterns. (See Kairouz etÂ al. (2019) for more on aspects of fairness and bias in FL.)

Mixed FL overcomes this problem, by training a model jointly on federated data (representative of users of higher-end phones) and a datacenter dataset (representative of users of lower-end phones). We simulate this scenario using two large public datasets: the Stack Overflow dataset111111Stack Overflow federated data available viaÂ (TFF StackOverflow documentation, 2022); see link for license.Â (Kaggle, ) for federated data, and the Wikipedia dataset121212Wikipedia data available viaÂ (TFDS Wikipedia documentation(2022), 20201201.en); see link for license.Â (Wikimedia Foundation, ) for datacenter data. Figure 1b shows results. The â€˜only FLâ€™ scenario learns Stack Overflow (but not Wikipedia) patterns of character usage, and so has limited accuracy (<0.45absent0.45<0.45) when evaluated on examples from both datasets. The mixed FL algorithms demonstrate learning both: they all achieve an evaluation accuracy (âˆ¼0.60similar-toabsent0.60\sim 0.60) comparable to an imagined â€˜oracleâ€™ that could centrally train on the combination of datasets. For training hyperparameters, additional experiments, and other details, see Appendix C.

Table 2 (center column) shows G~tsubscript~ğºğ‘¡\tilde{G}_{t} and B~tsubscript~ğµğ‘¡\tilde{B}_{t} for this problem. Unlike smile classification, here gradient dissimilarity is trivial: G~tâ‰ˆ0subscript~ğºğ‘¡0\tilde{G}_{t}\approx 0 and B~tâ‰ˆ1subscript~ğµğ‘¡1\tilde{B}_{t}\approx 1. This should mean Parallel Training is competitive. Figure 2b empirically confirms this to be true; the algorithms converge roughly equivalently.

5.3 Regularizing Embeddings at Server, for Movie Recommendation (MovieLens)

The third task we study is movie recommendation with an embedding regularization term, as described in Section 1. A key difference from the previous two scenarios is that here we perform mixed FL by mixing different loss functions instead of mixing datacenter and client datasets. We study this scenario by training a dual encoder representation learning model (Covington etÂ al., 2016) for next movie prediction on the MovieLens dataset (Harper and Konstan, 2015; GroupLens, ).

As described in Section 1, limited negative examples can degrade representation learning performance. Previous work (Ning etÂ al., 2021) proposed using losses insensitive to local client negatives to improve federated model performance. They observed significantly improved performance by using a two-part loss: (1) a hinge loss to pull embeddings for similar movies together, and (2) a spreadout regularization (Zhang etÂ al., 2017) to push embeddings for unrelated movies apart. For clients to calculate (2), the server must communicate all movie embeddings to each client, and clients must perform a matrix multiplication over the entire embedding table. This introduces enormous computation and communication overhead when the number of movies is large.

Mixed FL can alleviate this communication and computation overhead. Instead of computing both loss terms on clients, clients calculate only the hinge loss and the server calculates the expensive regularization term, avoiding costly computation on each client. Also, since computing the hinge loss term only requires movie embeddings corresponding to movies in a clientâ€™s local dataset, only those embeddings are sent to that client, saving communication and on-client memory.

Experiments show that all mixed FL algorithms achieve model performance (around 0.1 for recall@10) comparable to the baseline scenario where everything is computed on the clients. Moreover, mixed FL eliminates more than 99.9% of client computation and more than 93.9% of communication (see Table 5.3). For training hyperparameters, computation and communication savings analysis, additional experiments, and other task details, see Appendix C. Note that a real-world model can be much larger than this movie recommendation model131313E.g., for a next URL prediction task with millions of URLs the embedding table size can reach gigabytes.. Without mixed FL, communicating such large models to clients and computing the regularization term would be impractical in large-scale settings.

Figure 5.3 shows that Parallel Training converges slightly slower than either Gradient Transfer algorithm but reaches the same evaluation loss at around 1500 rounds. The approximated gradient dissimilarity metrics for this task are presented in the last column of Table 2.

6 Conclusion

This paper has introduced mixed FL, including motivation, algorithms and their convergence properties, and intuition for when a given algorithm will be useful for a given problem. Our experiments indicate mixed FL can improve accuracy and reduce communication and computation across tasks.

This work focused on jointly learning from a single decentralized client population and a centralized entity, as it illuminates the key aspects of the mixed FL problem. Note that mixed FL and the associated properties we define in this paper (like mixed FL (G,BğºğµG,B)-BGD) are easily expanded to work with multiple (>1absent1>1) distinct client populations participating. E.g., a population of mobile phones and a separate population of smart speakers, or mobile phones separated into populations with distinct capabilities/usage (high-end vs.Â low-end, or by country/language). Also, there need not be a centralized entity; mixing can be solely between distinct federated datasets.

It is interesting to reflect on the bounds of Table 1, and what they indicate about the benefits of separating a single decentralized client population into multiple populations for mixed FL purposes. The bounds are in terms of Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} (representing within population â€˜variabilityâ€™) and GğºG and BğµB (representing cross-population â€˜variabilityâ€™). Splitting a population based on traits will likely decrease Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} (each population is now more homogeneous) but introduce or increase GğºG and BğµB (populations are now distinctive). This might indicate scenarios where Gradient Transfer methods (only bounded by Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}) become more useful and Parallel Training (also bound by GğºG and BğµB) becomes less useful.

The limits of our convergence bounds should be noted. First, they are â€˜looseâ€™; practical performance in particular algorithmic scenarios could be better, and thus comparisons between algorithms could differ. Second, our bounds assume IID federated data, which is invalid in practice; convergence properties differ on non-IID data. While our analysis, extended to handle non-IID data, shows that the bounds do not materially change, it is still a place where theory and practice slightly diverge.

Adaptive optimization (Reddi etÂ al., 2020) with mixed FL has not been explored adequately. Preliminary results with FedADAM are given (Appendix C.4.4), but further study is required. Application of adaptivity could positively impact practical convergence experience.

In principle, mixed FL techniques are expected to have positive societal impacts insofar as they further develop the toolkit for FL (which has security and privacy benefits to users) and improve accuracy on final inference distributions. Also, weâ€™ve shown (Section 5.2) how mixed FL can address participation biases that arise in FL. However, the addition of server-based data to federated optimization raises the possibility that biases in large public corpora find their way into more applications of FL.

Appendix A Practical Implementation Details

A.1 Download Size

Gradient Transfer (either 1-way or 2-way) requires sending additional data as part of the communication from server to clients at the start of a federated round. Apart from the usual model checkpoint weights, with Gradient Transfer we must now also transmit gradients of the model weights w.r.tÂ centralized data as well. Naively, this doubles the download size as the gradient is the same size as the model. However, the centralized gradients should be amenable to compression, e.g. using an approach such as Mitchell etÂ al. [2022].

A.2 Upload Size

With Parallel Training and 1-way Gradient Transfer, no client gradient information is used outside of the clients themselves, so there is no additional information (apart from the model deltas and aggregation weights) to upload to the server. With 2-way Gradient Transfer, client gradient information is used as part of centralized training, and thus needs to be conveyed back to the server somehow.

When the FL client optimization is SGD, the average client gradient in a round (over all clients participating, over all steps) can be determined from the model deltas and aggregation weights that are already being sent back to the server, meaning no additional upload bandwidth is necessary. The algorithm to do this is as follows.

Each client iğ‘–i transmits back to the server a local model change Î”i(t)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Delta_{i}^{(t)} and an aggregation weight pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} that is typically related to number of steps taken Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}. The average total gradient applied at client iğ‘–i during round tğ‘¡t is:

gÂ¯(t)=âˆ’1Î·â€‹Kiâ€‹Î”i(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘”ğ‘¡1ğœ‚subscriptğ¾ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\bar{g}^{(t)}=-\frac{1}{\eta K_{i}}\Delta_{i}^{(t)} (8)

The average client gradient (i.e., w.r.t.Â just client data) at client iğ‘–i is:

gÂ¯i(t)=âˆ’1Î·â€‹Kiâ€‹Î”i(t)âˆ’g~c(t)superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘¡1ğœ‚subscriptğ¾ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript~ğ‘”cğ‘¡\bar{g}_{i}^{(t)}=-\frac{1}{\eta K_{i}}\Delta_{i}^{(t)}-\tilde{g}_{\textrm{c}}^{(t)} (9)

where g~c(t)superscriptsubscript~ğ‘”cğ‘¡\tilde{g}_{\textrm{c}}^{(t)} is the augmenting centralized gradient that was calculated from centralized data and used in round tğ‘¡t. The average (across the cohort) of average client gradients, weighted by Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}, is:

gÂ¯f(t)=âˆ’1Î·â€‹âˆ‘iKiâ€‹âˆ‘iÎ”i(t)âˆ’g~c(t)superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘”fğ‘¡1ğœ‚subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript~ğ‘”cğ‘¡\bar{g}_{\textrm{f}}^{(t)}=-\frac{1}{\eta\sum_{i}K_{i}}\sum_{i}\Delta_{i}^{(t)}-\tilde{g}_{\textrm{c}}^{(t)} (10)

This average client gradient gÂ¯f(t)superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘”fğ‘¡\bar{g}_{\textrm{f}}^{(t)} is in the spirit of SCAFFOLD [Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b] Equation 4, Option II. It will be used as the augmenting federated gradient g~f(t+1)superscriptsubscript~ğ‘”fğ‘¡1\tilde{g}_{\textrm{f}}^{(t+1)} in the subsequent round t+1ğ‘¡1t+1, to augment centralized optimization. See Algorithm 1.

A.3 Debugging and Hyperparameter Intuition via K=1ğ¾1K=1

As these algorithms each involve different hyperparameters, validating that software implementations are behaving as expected is non-trivial. Something that proved useful for debugging purposes, as well as provided practical experience in understanding equivalences between the algorithms, was to perform test cases with the number of local steps Kğ¾K set to 1. In this setting, the three mixed FL algorithms are effectively identical and should make equivalent progress during training.

Note that the convergence bounds of Table 1 hold for Kâ‰¥2ğ¾2K\geq 2, so this takes us outside the operating regime where the bounds predict performance. It also takes us outside an operating regime that is typically useful (FL use cases generally find multiple steps per round to be beneficial). But it does serve a purpose when debugging.

Appendix B Convergence Theorems

The three subsections that follow state theorems for convergence (to an error smaller than Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) for the respective mixed FL algorithms. The convergence bounds are summarized in Table 1 in Section 4. Tables 3 and 4 convey some supporting aspects of the convergence bounds, about limits on effective step size (Î·~=Î·â€‹Î·sâ€‹K~ğœ‚ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚sğ¾\tilde{\eta}=\eta\eta_{\textrm{s}}K) and assumptions on learning rates.

Appendix C Experiments: Additional Information and Results

C.1 G~tsubscript~ğºğ‘¡\tilde{G}_{t} and B~tsubscript~ğµğ‘¡\tilde{B}_{t} Metrics Plots

Table 2 is an informative comparison of the mixed FL optimization landscape of the three respective experiments conducted in Section 5. It includes maximum values for the metrics G~tsubscript~ğºğ‘¡\tilde{G}_{t} and B~tsubscript~ğµğ‘¡\tilde{B}_{t} (the sampled approximations of the parameters defined in (G,BğºğµG,B)-BGD (Definition 4.2). C.2 Additional Details for Experiments in Section 5

General Notes on Hyperparameter Selection

For the various experiments in Section 5, we empirically determined good hyperparameter settings (as documented in Tables C.2-C.2). Our general approach for each task was to leave server learning rate Î·ssubscriptğœ‚s\eta_{\textrm{s}} at 1, select a number of steps Kğ¾K that made the most use of the examples in each clientâ€™s cache, and then do a sweep of client learning rates Î·ğœ‚\eta to determine a setting that was fast but didnâ€™t diverge. For Parallel Training and 2-way Gradient Transfer, which involve central optimization and merging, we set the merging learning rate Î·msubscriptğœ‚m\eta_{\textrm{m}} to be 1, and set the central learning rate Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}} as the product of client and server learning rates: Î·c=Î·â€‹Î·ssubscriptğœ‚cğœ‚subscriptğœ‚s\eta_{\textrm{c}}=\eta\eta_{\textrm{s}} (and since Î·s=1subscriptğœ‚s1\eta_{\textrm{s}}=1, this meant client and central learning rates were equal).

General Notes on Comparing Algorithms

We generally kept hyperparameters equivalent when comparing the algorithms. For example, we aimed to set batch sizes for all algorithms such that central and client gradient variances Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} and Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} have equivalent impact on convergence (meaning |â„¬c|=Sâ€‹|â„¬i|subscriptâ„¬cğ‘†subscriptâ„¬ğ‘–|\mathcal{B}_{\textrm{c}}|=S|\mathcal{B}_{i}| for PT and 2-w GT, and |â„¬c|=Kâ€‹Sâ€‹|â„¬i|subscriptâ„¬cğ¾ğ‘†subscriptâ„¬ğ‘–|\mathcal{B}_{\textrm{c}}|=KS|\mathcal{B}_{i}| for 1-w GT). In the case of language model training with 1-way Gradient Transfer, following this rubric would have meant a central batch size |â„¬c|subscriptâ„¬c|\mathcal{B}_{\textrm{c}}| of 12800; we reduced this in half for practical computation reasons. For a given task, we also generally kept learning rates the same for all algorithms. Interestingly, we observed that as Î·ğœ‚\eta (and Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}}, if applicable) is increased for a given task, the 2-way Gradient Transfer algorithm is the first of the three to diverge, and so we had to adjust, e.g., in the language modeling experiment we used a lower Î·ğœ‚\eta for 2-w GT than for PT and 1-w GT.

C.2.1 CelebA Smile Classification

Datasets

The CelebA federated dataset consists of 9,343 raw clients, which can be broken into train/evaluation splits of 8,408/935 clients, respectively [TFF CelebA documentation, 2022]. The raw clients have average cache size of âˆ¼21similar-toabsent21\sim 21 face images. The images are about equally split between smiling and unsmiling faces. In order to enlarge cache size, we group three raw clients together into one composite client, so our federated training data involves 2,802 clients with caches of (on average) âˆ¼63similar-toabsent63\sim 63 face images (and about half that when we limit the clients to only have smiling faces).

Our evaluation data consists of both smiling and unsmiling faces, and is meant to stand in for the inference distribution (where accurate classification of both smiling and unsmiling inputs is necessary). Note that as CelebA contains smiling and unsmiling faces in nearly equal amounts, a high evaluation accuracy cannot come at the expense of one particular label being poorly classified.

Model Architecture

The architecture used is a very basic fully-connected neural network141414Adapted from an online tutorial involving CelebA binary attribute classification: â€œTensorFlow Constrained Optimization Example Using CelebA Datasetâ€.Â with a single hidden layer of 64 neurons with ReLU activations.

Hyperparameter Settings

The settings used in mixed FL training are shown in Tables C.2 and C.2.

C.2.2 Stack Overflow/Wikipedia Language Modeling

Datasets

The Stack Overflow dataset is a large-scale federated dataset, consisting of 342,477 training clients and 204,088 evaluation clients [TFF StackOverflow documentation, 2022]. The training clients have average cache size of âˆ¼400similar-toabsent400\sim 400 examples, and evaluation clients have average cache size of âˆ¼80similar-toabsent80\sim 80 examples. The Wikipedia dataset (wikipedia/20201201.en) consists of 6,210,110 examples [TFDS Wikipedia documentation(2022), 20201201.en]. The raw text data is processed into sequences of 100 characters.

Our evaluation data is a combined dataset consisting of randomly shuffled examples drawn from the Stack Overflow evaluation clients and the Wikipedia dataset.

Model Architecture

The architecture used is a recurrent neural network (RNN)151515Adapted from an online tutorial involving next character prediction: â€œText generation with an RNNâ€.Â with an embedding dimension of 256 and 1024 GRU units.

Hyperparameter Settings

The settings used in mixed FL training are shown in Tables C.2 and C.2.

Evaluation Accuracy on Individual Data Splits

Figure 4 shows the accuracy of models (trained either via mixed FL or pure FL) when evaluated on only federated data (Stack Overflow) or only centralized data (Wikipedia) individually. Confirming what we expect, the various mixed FL algorithms do a good job of achieving accuracy on both datasets. But if we train only via FL (without mixing), then we do a good job of learning the federated data (Stack Overflow) character sequences, but arenâ€™t nearly as accurate at predicting the next character in centralized data (Wikipedia) sequences.

C.2.3 MovieLens Movie Recommendation

Dataset

The MovieLens 1M dataset [GroupLens, ] contains approximately 1 million ratings from 6,040 users on 3,952 movies. Examples are grouped by user, forming a natural data partitioning across clients. For all mixed FL algorithms we study, we keep examples from 20% of users (randomly selecting 20% of users and shuffling the examples of these users) as the datacenter data, and use examples from the remaining 80% users as client data. With this data splitting strategy, the server data wonâ€™t include the same individual client distributions but it will still be sampled from the same meta distribution of clients. We then split the clients data into the train and test sets, resulting in 3,865 train, 483 validation, and 483 test users. The average cache size of each client is âˆ¼160similar-toabsent160\sim 160 examples.

Model Architecture

The architecture used is the same as Ning etÂ al. [2021], a dual encoder representation learning model with a bag-of-word encoder for the left tower (which takes in a list of movies a user has seen) and a simple embedding lookup encoder for the right tower (which takes in the next movie a user sees).

Hyperparameter Settings

The settings used in mixed FL training are shown in Tables C.2 and C.2.

Recall@10

As mentioned in Subsection 5.3, all mixed FL algorithms achieved similar global recall@10 compared to the baseline. Figure 5 shows evaluation recall@10 over 2000 training rounds.

C.3 Computation and Communication Savings for Movie Recommendation

This section provides a detailed analysis of the computation and communication savings brought by mixed FL in the movie recommendation task.

For movie recommendation, both the input feature and the label are movie IDs with a vocabulary size of Nğ‘N. They share the same embedding table, with an embedding dimension of dğ‘‘d. The input features and label embedding layers account for most of the model parameters in a dual encoder. Therefore, we use the total size of the feature and label embeddings to approximate the model size: M=(N+N)â‹…dğ‘€â‹…ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘M=(N+N)\cdot d. Batch size is â„¬isubscriptâ„¬ğ‘–\mathcal{B}_{i} and local steps per round is Kğ¾K. Let the averaged number of movies in each clientâ€™s local dataset for each training round be nğ‘›n, smaller than â„¬iâ‹…Kâ‹…subscriptâ„¬ğ‘–ğ¾\mathcal{B}_{i}\cdot K.

Computation

When computing the regularization term on the server (mixed FL), the complexity is (N2â‹…d)/2â‹…superscriptğ‘2ğ‘‘2(N^{2}\cdot d)/2. The total computation saving with mixed FL is ((Kâˆ’1)â‹…N2â‹…d)/2â‹…ğ¾1superscriptğ‘2ğ‘‘2((K-1)\cdot N^{2}\cdot d)/2. We use (N2â‹…d)/2â‹…superscriptğ‘2ğ‘‘2(N^{2}\cdot d)/2 instead of N2â‹…dâ‹…superscriptğ‘2ğ‘‘N^{2}\cdot d for regularization term computation which is more accurate for an optimized implementation.

The total computation complexity of the forward pass is Oâ€‹(â„¬iâ€‹d+â„¬iâ€‹d2+â„¬i2â€‹d)ğ‘‚subscriptâ„¬ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„¬ğ‘–superscriptğ‘‘2superscriptsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘–2ğ‘‘O(\mathcal{B}_{i}d+\mathcal{B}_{i}d^{2}+\mathcal{B}_{i}^{2}d), where the three items are for the bag-of-word encoder, the context hidden layer, and similarity calculation. Communication

The communication overheads of each algorithm are presented in the last row of Table 5. For the baseline, the server and each client need to communicate the full embedding table and the gradients, so the communication overhead is 2â‹…Nâ‹…dâ‹…2ğ‘ğ‘‘2\cdot N\cdot d or 494KB. With Parallel Training, the server and each client only communicate movie embeddings and the gradients corresponding to movies in that clientâ€™s local datasets. Thus the communication traffic is reduced to 2â‹…nâ‹…dâ‹…2ğ‘›ğ‘‘2\cdot n\cdot d or 20KB. Gradient Transfer requires the server to send both the movie embeddings and gradients to each client. The communication overhead then becomes 3â‹…nâ‹…dâ‹…3ğ‘›ğ‘‘3\cdot n\cdot d or 30KB. Overall, mixed FL can save more than 93.9% communication overhead than the baseline.

C.4 Additional Observations and Experiments

C.4.1 Effect of Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} on convergence

Table 1 shows that the theoretical bounds on rounds to convergence are directly proportional to the client variance bound Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} and central variance bound Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2}. Also, as discussed in Subsection 4.2, 1-way Gradient Transfer is more sensitive to high central variance than the other two algorithms. Whereas in the other algorithms the impact of Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} on convergence scales with cohort size Sğ‘†S, in 1-way Gradient Transfer it scales with cohort size Sğ‘†S and steps taken per round Kğ¾K.

To observe the effect of Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} in practice, and compare its effect on 1-way Gradient Transfer vs.Â 2-way Gradient Transfer, we ran sweeps of CelebA smile classification training, varying the central batch size |â„¬c|subscriptâ„¬c|\mathcal{B}_{\textrm{c}}|. The plots of evaluation loss and evaluation AUC of ROC are shown in Figures 6 (1-w GT) and 7 (2-w GT). For each central batch size setting, we ran 10 trials; the plots show the means of each settingâ€™s trials, with corresponding 95% confidence bounds.

Figure 6 confirms the sensitivity of 1-way Gradient Transfer to central variance, with experiments using larger central batches â„¬csubscriptâ„¬c\mathcal{B}_{\textrm{c}} converging faster than experiments using smaller central batches. However, at least in the case of this task, the benefits of lower variance disappear quickly. The convergence of AUC of ROC did not appreciably improve for central batch sizes larger than 25. Presumably there is little effect at these larger central batch sizes because in these cases the convergence is now dominated by client variance (i.e., further convergence improvements would come from increasing client batch size |â„¬i|subscriptâ„¬ğ‘–|\mathcal{B}_{i}|).

Comparing Figure 7 with Figure 6, we empirically observe that 2-way Gradient Transfer has lower sensitivity than 1-way Gradient Transfer to central batch size/central variance.

C.4.2 Trading Î·ğœ‚\eta for Kğ¾K

The convergence bounds of Table 1 have an additional implication, in regards to the trade off between client learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta (and central learning rate Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}}) and number of local steps taken Kğ¾K.

Itâ€™s better to reduce Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}} and increase Kğ¾K, but there are limits

The convergence bounds are not related to client or central learning rate (Î·ğœ‚\eta or Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}}), but are inversely related to local steps Kğ¾K. In general, itâ€™s best to take as many steps as possible, and if necessary reduce learning rates accordingly. But there are limits to how large Kğ¾K can be. First, clients have finite caches of data, and Kğ¾K will always be limited by cache size divided by batch size. Second, in the case of 1-way Gradient Transfer, any increase in Kğ¾K means that central variance Ïƒc2superscriptsubscriptğœc2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} must be proportionally reduced (as mentioned above), necessitating even larger central batch sizes (which at some point is infeasible).

We empirically observed this relationship by running smile classification (Figure 8) and language modeling (Figure 9) experiments where client learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta (and central learning rate Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}}) are inversely proportionally varied with Kğ¾K. For each hyperparameter configuration we ran 5 trials; the figures include 95% confidence intervals. The results confirm that reducing these learning rates, and making a corresponding increase in the number of steps, is beneficial. It never hurts convergence, and often helps.

C.4.3 Differences in effective step size

Table 3 in Appendix B shows that in order to yield the convergence bounds stated in this paper, each algorithm makes different assumptions of maximum effective step size. From this we draw one final implication in regards to comparing the mixed FL algorithms.

For given Î·ğœ‚\eta, maximum Kğ¾K varies by algorithm, or, for given Kğ¾K, maximum Î·ğœ‚\eta varies by algorithm

Consider just effective federated step size Î·~=Î·â€‹Î·sâ€‹K~ğœ‚ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚sğ¾\tilde{\eta}=\eta\eta_{\textrm{s}}K for the moment. Assume that server learning rate Î·ssubscriptğœ‚s\eta_{\textrm{s}} is held constant. Then each mixed FL algorithm has a different theoretical upper bound on the product of client learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta and local steps per round Kğ¾K. If using a common Î·ğœ‚\eta, the theoretical upper limit on Kğ¾K varies by mixed FL algorithm. Alternatively if using a common Kğ¾K, the theoretical upper limit on Î·ğœ‚\eta varies by mixed FL algorithm.

The maximum effective step sizes of Table 3 imply that 2-way Gradient Transfer has narrower limits than 1-way Gradient Transfer on the allowable ranges of Î·ğœ‚\eta and Kğ¾K. It also indicates that for Parallel Training the allowable range of Î·ğœ‚\eta, Î·csubscriptğœ‚c\eta_{\textrm{c}}, and Kğ¾K depends on the BğµB parameter from mixed FL (G,BğºğµG,B)-BGD (Definition 4.2).

Some of this behavior has been observed empirically, when hyperparameter tuning our experiments (discussed in Subsection C.2). For example, for the language modeling experiment, assuming a constant number of steps of K=16ğ¾16K=16, 2-way Gradient Transfer tends to diverge when learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta was increased beyond 1.0, whereas 1-way Gradient Transfer is observed to converge even with learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta of 5.0. (Parallel Training is in-between; it still converges with learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta of 3.0, but diverges when learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta is 5.0.) An interesting characteristic to note is that using different Î·ğœ‚\eta in different algorithms does not really impact comparative convergence. Figure 10 shows convergence in the language modeling experiment, when 2-way Gradient Transfer uses Î·=1.0ğœ‚1.0\eta=1.0 and 1-way Gradient Transfer and Parallel Training both use Î·=3.0ğœ‚3.0\eta=3.0 (in all cases, with K=16ğ¾16K=16). The higher learning rate of 1-w GT and PT helps a little early, but does not impact the number of rounds to convergence. This holds with the theoretical convergence bounds of Table 1, which show a relationship with steps Kğ¾K but not learning rates (as also discussed above).

C.4.4 1-w GT with adaptive optimization

We briefly studied the performance of 1-way Gradient Transfer when using ADAM in place of SGD as the server optimizer, i.e., FedADAM [Reddi etÂ al., 2020]. Note that the server adaptive optimizer requires a smaller learning rate to perform well. Figure 11 reports the results of using ADAM as the server optimizer with a server learning rate of 0.01. All the other hyperparameters are the same as in Tables C.2 and C.2. We observe that (1) ADAM works better than SGD, leading to better convergence, and (2) 1-way Gradient Transfer performs almost the same as the baseline when using ADAM. We will extend our investigation of mixed FL with adaptive optimization in the future. This will include studying methods for applying adaptive optimization to Parallel Training and 2-way Gradient Transfer; these algorithms are more complicated since they involve additional optimizers (CentralOpt and MergeOpt).

Appendix D Convergence Proofs for 1-way Gradient Transfer

We will prove the convergence rate of 1-way Gradient Transfer for 3 different cases: Strongly convex, general convex, and non-convex. We will first state a number of definitions and lemmas in Subsection D.1 that are needed in proving convergence rate of 1-way Gradient Transfer, before proceeding to the actual proofs in Subsection D.2.

D.1 Additional Definitions and Lemmas

Note that some of the lemmas below are restatements of lemmas given in Karimireddy etÂ al. [2020b]. We opt to restate here (versus referencing the relevant lemma in Karimireddy etÂ al. [2020b] each time) due to the volume of usage of the lemmas, to ease the burden on the reader.

We will first present the subset of definitions and lemmas which donâ€™t make any assumptions of convexity (Subsection D.1.1), followed by the subset that assume convexity (Subsection D.1.2)

The claimed bound then follows from the above two facts. âˆ

Proposition D.6 (Convex bound on gradient of overall loss).

If client losses fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} and centralized loss fcsubscriptğ‘“cf_{\textrm{c}} are each Î¼ğœ‡\mu-convex (Definition D.4) and Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth (Definition D.1), and ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\bm{x}^{*} is an optimum of the overall loss fğ‘“f (as defined in Equation 1), then the expected norm of the gradient of overall loss is bounded as:

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤4â€‹Î²â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)]ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™24ğ›½ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f(\bm{x})\right\|^{2}\leq 4\beta\mathbb{E}\left[f(\bm{x})-f(\bm{x}^{*})\right]
Proof.
ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2=ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)â€–2=ğ”¼â€‹â€–1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1N(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))+(âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))â€–2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ’™2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“csuperscriptğ’™2\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f(\bm{x})\right\|^{2}&=\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{x}^{*})\right\|^{2}\\ &=\mathbb{E}\left\|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}^{*})\right)+\left(\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}^{*})\right)\right\|^{2}\\ \end{split}

Applying the relaxed triangle inequality (Lemma D.2) twice:

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹â€–1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1N(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))â€–2+2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))â€–2+2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))â€–2+â€–âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fcâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)â€–2]ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“csuperscriptğ’™22ğ”¼1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“csuperscriptğ’™22ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“cğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“csuperscriptğ’™2\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f(\bm{x})\right\|^{2}&\leq 2\mathbb{E}\left\|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}^{*})\right)\right\|^{2}+2\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}^{*})\right\|^{2}\\ &\leq 2\mathbb{E}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|\left(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}^{*})\right)\right\|^{2}+2\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}^{*})\right\|^{2}\\ &\leq 2\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|\left(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}^{*})\right)\right\|^{2}+\left\|\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}^{*})\right\|^{2}\right]\end{split}

Applying Proposition D.5:

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[2â€‹Î²â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))]â‰¤4â€‹Î²â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)]ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™22ğ”¼delimited-[]2ğ›½ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™4ğ›½ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f(\bm{x})\right\|^{2}&\leq 2\mathbb{E}\left[2\beta\left(f(\bm{x})-f(\bm{x}^{*})\right)\right]\\ &\leq 4\beta\mathbb{E}\left[f(\bm{x})-f(\bm{x}^{*})\right]\end{split}

âˆ

Lemma D.7 (Perturbed strong convexity).

The following holds for any Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth and Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly-convex function hâ„h, and any ğ±ğ±\bm{x}, ğ²ğ²\bm{y}, ğ³ğ³\bm{z} in the domain of hâ„h:

âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™),ğ’›âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¥hâ€‹(ğ’›)âˆ’hâ€‹(ğ’š)+Î¼4â€‹â€–ğ’šâˆ’ğ’›â€–2âˆ’Î²â€‹â€–ğ’›âˆ’ğ’™â€–2âˆ‡â„ğ’™ğ’›ğ’šâ„ğ’›â„ğ’šğœ‡4superscriptnormğ’šğ’›2ğ›½superscriptnormğ’›ğ’™2\left\langle\nabla h(\bm{x}),\bm{z}-\bm{y}\right\rangle\geq h(\bm{z})-h(\bm{y})+\frac{\mu}{4}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{z}\right\|^{2}-\beta\left\|\bm{z}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}
Proof.

Given any ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x}, ğ’šğ’š\bm{y}, and ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z}, we get the following two inequalities using smoothness (Definition D.1) and strong convexity (Definition D.4) of hâ„h:

âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™),ğ’›âˆ’ğ’™âŸ©â‰¥hâ€‹(ğ’›)âˆ’hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’Î²2â€‹â€–ğ’›âˆ’ğ’™â€–2â‰¥hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’hâ€‹(ğ’š)+Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™â€–2âˆ‡â„ğ’™ğ’›ğ’™â„ğ’›â„ğ’™ğ›½2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’›ğ’™2â„ğ’™â„ğ’šğœ‡2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’šğ’™2\begin{split}\left\langle\nabla h(\bm{x}),\bm{z}-\bm{x}\right\rangle\geq&h(\bm{z})-h(\bm{x})-\frac{\beta}{2}\left\|\bm{z}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}\\ \geq&h(\bm{x})-h(\bm{y})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}\\ \end{split}

Further, applying the relaxed triangle inequality (Lemma D.2) gives:

Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™â€–2â‰¥Î¼4â€‹â€–ğ’šâˆ’ğ’›â€–2âˆ’Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’›â€–2ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ’šğ’™2ğœ‡4superscriptnormğ’šğ’›2ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ’™ğ’›2\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}\geq\frac{\mu}{4}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{z}\right\|^{2}-\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{z}\right\|^{2}

Combining all the inequalities together we have:

âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™),ğ’›âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¥hâ€‹(ğ’›)âˆ’hâ€‹(ğ’š)+Î¼4â€‹â€–ğ’šâˆ’ğ’›â€–2âˆ’Î²+Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ’›âˆ’ğ’™â€–2âˆ‡â„ğ’™ğ’›ğ’šâ„ğ’›â„ğ’šğœ‡4superscriptnormğ’šğ’›2ğ›½ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ’›ğ’™2\left\langle\nabla h(\bm{x}),\bm{z}-\bm{y}\right\rangle\geq h(\bm{z})-h(\bm{y})+\frac{\mu}{4}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{z}\right\|^{2}-\frac{\beta+\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{z}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}

The lemma follows since Î²â‰¥Î¼ğ›½ğœ‡\beta\geq\mu. âˆ

Lemma D.8 (Contractive mapping).

For any Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth and Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex function hâ„h, values ğ±ğ±\bm{x} and ğ²ğ²\bm{y} in the domain of hâ„h, and step-size (learning rate) Î·â‰¤1Î²ğœ‚1ğ›½\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta}, the following holds true:

â€–ğ’™âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’ğ’š+Î·â€‹âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š)â€–2â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·)â€‹â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2superscriptnormğ’™ğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™ğ’šğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’š21ğœ‡ğœ‚superscriptnormğ’™ğ’š2\left\|\bm{x}-\eta\nabla h(\bm{x})-\bm{y}+\eta\nabla h(\bm{y})\right\|^{2}\leq\left(1-\mu\eta\right)\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|^{2}
Proof.

Expanding terms, and applying smoothness (Definition D.1):

â€–ğ’™âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’ğ’š+Î·â€‹âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š)â€–2=â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2+Î·2â€‹â€–âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š)â€–2âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¤â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2+(Î·2â€‹Î²âˆ’2â€‹Î·)â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©formulae-sequencesuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’™ğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™ğ’šğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’š2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’™ğ’š2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡â„ğ’™âˆ‡â„ğ’š22ğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™âˆ‡â„ğ’šğ’™ğ’šsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’™ğ’š2superscriptğœ‚2ğ›½2ğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™âˆ‡â„ğ’šğ’™ğ’š\begin{split}\left\|\bm{x}-\eta\nabla h(\bm{x})-\bm{y}+\eta\nabla h(\bm{y})\right\|^{2}&=\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|^{2}+\eta^{2}\left\|\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y})\right\|^{2}\\ &\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad-2\eta\langle\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y}),\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rangle\\ &\leq\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|^{2}+\left(\eta^{2}\beta-2\eta\right)\langle\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y}),\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rangle\end{split}

If step-size is such that Î·â‰¤1Î²ğœ‚1ğ›½\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta}, then:

(Î·2â€‹Î²âˆ’2â€‹Î·)â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¤âˆ’Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©superscriptğœ‚2ğ›½2ğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™âˆ‡â„ğ’šğ’™ğ’šğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™âˆ‡â„ğ’šğ’™ğ’š\left(\eta^{2}\beta-2\eta\right)\langle\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y}),\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rangle\leq-\eta\langle\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y}),\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rangle

Finally, for Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strong convexity (Definition D.4) of hâ„h we have:

âˆ’Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡hâ€‹(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¤âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2ğœ‚âˆ‡â„ğ’™âˆ‡â„ğ’šğ’™ğ’šğœ‡ğœ‚superscriptnormğ’™ğ’š2-\eta\langle\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y}),\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rangle\leq-\mu\eta\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|^{2}

Lemma D.9 (Bound on variance of server update).

The variance of the server update is bounded as:

â‰¤ğ”¼|tâ€‹[â€–Î·~Kâ€‹Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®âˆ‘k=1K(giâ€‹(ğ’™i(t,k))âˆ’âˆ‡ffâ€‹(ğ’™(t)))+(âˆ‡ffâ€‹(ğ’™(t))+gcâ€‹(ğ’™(t)))â€–2]\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{|t}\left[\left\|\frac{\tilde{\eta}}{KS}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(g_{i}(\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)})-\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}(\bm{x}^{(t)})\right)+\left(\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}(\bm{x}^{(t)})+g_{\textrm{c}}(\bm{x}^{(t)})\right)\right\|^{2}\right]

We then combine the two lemmas together to give the proofs of convergence rate for the strongly convex (Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0) and general convex (Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0) cases.

D.2.2 Non-Convex Case

We will now prove the rate of convergence stated in Theorem B.2 for the non-convex case for 1-way Gradient Transfer. We will state two lemmas, one (Lemma D.12) establishing the progress made in each round, and one (Lemma D.13) bounding how much the federated clients â€˜driftâ€™ in a round during the course of local training. We then combine the two lemmas together give the proof of convergence rate for the non-convex case.

Lemma D.12 (Non-convex one round progress).

The progress made in a round can be bounded as:
